ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:0.5_0: The training rule on taking back robe-cloth
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.2_0: At that time Venerable Upananda the Sakyan said to his brother’s student,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.3_0: “Come, let’s go wandering in the country.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.7_0: And he gave him a robe.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.11_0: He replied, “I’m not going with Venerable Upananda.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.14_0: he replied, “I’m not going with you, but with the Buddha.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.15_0: “I’ve given you a robe with me.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.16_0: and he just took it back in anger.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.18_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.19_0: “How can Venerable Upananda give away a robe and then take it back in anger?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.20_0: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Upananda:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.21_0: “Is it true, Upananda, that you acted like this?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.24_0: “... Foolish man, how can you give a robe to a monk and then take it back in anger?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.25_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.26_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.27.1_0: ‘If a monk gives a robe to a monk and then takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.4_0: ...The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.10_0: one of the six kinds of robe-cloth, but not smaller than what can be transferred to another.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.14_0: if he takes it back himself, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.16_0: if he asks another, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.17_0: If he only asks once, then even if the other takes back many, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.18_0: The blanket should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.19_0: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this. ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.21_0: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth which I took back after giving it to a monk is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.24_0: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.25.1_0: If the other monk is fully ordained, and he perceives him as such, and after giving him robe-cloth, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.26_0: If the other monk is fully ordained, but he is unsure of it, and after giving him robe-cloth, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.27_0: If the other monk is fully ordained, but he does not perceive him as such, and after giving him robe-cloth, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.28_0: If, after giving him another requisite, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.29_0: If, after giving robe-cloth to one who is not fully ordained, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.30_0: If the other person is not fully ordained, but he perceives them as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.31_0: If the other person is not fully ordained, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.32_0: If the other person is not fully ordained, and he does not perceive them as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.33.1_0: there is no offense for him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.34_0: if the other monk gives it back;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.35_0: if he takes it on trust from him;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.37_0: if he is the first offender.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.38_0: The fifth rule, the training rule on taking back robe-cloth, is finished.
